I hope we have been able to make you better understand how we differentiate, how we are positioned today, and how we will be positioned in the long term as well.

Any feedback, as I said, that you may have please do forward it to us, either through the form or just verbally to me, so that we can make sure that our next CMD is even better than today. So positive and negative feedback happily taken. And yes, I think with that, we're concluding this event. So those of you leaving Helsinki, safe travels home. And we look forward to seeing you very soon.

JAAKKO ESKOLA: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5T2P-YKC1-JCMN-Y20D-00000-00Warum die FinTech-Startups nicht das eigentliche Problem der Banken sind #32018-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:59ZLexisNexisWarum die FinTech-Startups nicht das eigentliche Problem der Banken sind #3rkeuper

Aug 19, 2018( Bankstil: https://bankstil.de Delivered by Newstex) Von Ralf Keuper Obgleich in den Medien zuweilen ein anderer Eindruck entstehen mag, ist die wirtschaftliche Bedeutung der Fintech-Startups bescheiden. Miriam Wohlfahrt gibt inDeutschlands Fintech-Szene ist aktiv wie nie[1] zu bedenken:Nach wie vor hat die kleinste aller deutschen Sparkassen Bad Sachsa eine hnliche Bilanz wie N26, das wird in der allgemeinen Nachrichtenlage gerne übersehen.Eine echte Bedrohung für die Banken geht von ihnen nicht aus. Eine Revolution, Disruption, ja selbst eine Evolution sieht anders aus.

Auch die bekanntesten und erfolgreichsten unter ihnen plagen sich mit Problemen, die für deutliche Risse in der Fassade sorgen, wie bei Revolut (Vgl. dazu:Customer fury at Nikolay Storonsky's Revolut lock-out[2]). Für noch mehr Ernüchterung sorgt hufig ein Blick in die Bilanzen, wie bei der solarisbank (Vgl. dazu:Exklusiv: Die Solarisbank kommt gerade mal auf echte Ertrge in Höhe von 2 Mio. Euro[3]). Der langjhrige Liebling der Szene, die Fidor Bank, ist seit einiger Zeit Teil der zweitgröten französischen Bankengruppe, der Groupe BPCE[4]. Bei der solarisbank und N26 sind überdies Banken und Technologiekonzerne engagiert. Ohne Anschluss an ein groes digitales kosystem haben die meisten Fintech-Startups auf Dauer keine berlebenschance. (Vgl. dazu:Moven wird zu einer 'gewöhnlichen' Bank mit Anschluss an ein groes digitales kosystem[5]). Echte Challenger-Banken gibt es nach Ansicht von PwC ohnehin nicht (Vgl. dazu:There is no such thing as a challenger bank (PWC)[6]). In den nchsten Jahren, so ein Tenor der Studie, wird die Zahl der Challenger Banken sinken; nur wenige werden den Spagat zwischen rascher Skalierung und Profitabilitt schaffen und ein tragfhiges Geschftsmodell entwickeln. Das gilt in hohem Ma für die Challenger Banken mit Vollbanklizenz. Die regulatorischen Anforderungen sorgen hier für einen Kostenblock, der im Tagesgeschft erst einmal verdient werden muss. Früher oder spter werden, ja müssen die Challenger Banken, der Logik des Bankgeschfts folgend, zu 'normalen' Banken werden (Eigenzitat). Die eigentliche Bedrohung geht von den Internetkonzernen aus. Die Banken sind mittlerweile von Google .... abhngig (Vgl. dazu:Big Tech und Banking: Darum wird daraus nichts).[7] Die Banken haben ihre digitale Souvernitt[8] verloren, die Fintech-Startups haben sie nie besessen.hnliche Beitrge [ 1]: https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/bilanz/article181072174/Die-Zahlenfrau-Deutschlands-Fintech-Szene-ist-aktiv-wie-nie.html [ 2]:   https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/customer-fury-at-nikolay-storonskys-revolut-lock-out-rgr2kbs2c [ 3]:   http://finanz-szene.de/14-08-18-ertragsschock-fuer-solarisbank-euphorie-um-kwitt-was-kann-die-blockchain/ [ 4]:   https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Groupe_BPCE [ 5]:   https://bankstil.de/moven-wird-zu-einer-gewoehnlichen-bank-mit-anschluss-an-ein-grosses-digitales-oekosystem [ 6]:   https://bankstil.de/there-is-no-such-thing-as-a-challenger-bank-pwc [ 7]:   https://www.finews.ch/news/banken/32824-big-tech-banking-analyse-wettbewerb-daten-regulierung [ 8]:   https://bankstil.de/das-ende-der-digitalen-souveranitat-der-banken

urn:contentItem:60SJ-YWY1-JCSC-J1V0-00000-00Wary of China, the West closes ranks to set rules for artificial intelligence2020-09-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:59ZLexisNexisNEWSWary of China, the West closes ranks to set rules for artificial intelligenceJanosch Delcker

In late February, U.S. Deputy Chief Technology Officer Lynn Parker traveled to Paris with a mission. She had come for a meeting with other government officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and she wanted to spread th... In late February, U.S. Deputy Chief Technology Officer Lynn Parker traveled to Paris with a mission....

In late February, U.S. Deputy Chief Technology Officer Lynn Parker traveled to Paris with a mission. She had come for a meeting with other government officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and she wanted to spread th...

In late February, U.S. Deputy Chief Technology Officer Lynn Parker traveled to Paris with a mission. She had come for a meeting with other government officials at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and she wanted to spread the word that it was high time for the West to join forces and beat China at writing the global rules for artificial intelligence. Parker’s plea came as a surprise to others. Less than two years earlier, Donald Trump’s White House had rejected a similar pitch by France and Canada during a Group of Seven (G7) meeting, arguing that international rules for AI would be premature and hamper innovation. But China’s blatant ambitions to become the world leader in AI had since alarmed U.S. policymakers and tech executives. Not only was Beijing pouring billions into the research and development of AI, but reports also suggested that the Chinese government was using it to build up an all-seeing surveillance state. And it was becoming increasingly clear that, as the country’s tech giants were exporting their technology around the globe, China was pushing for its ideas to become international standards. This convinced the White House that, despite differences with its allies over what rules are needed, Western countries should band together to make sure their companies, rather than Beijing’s, remained at the forefront of developing AI. Europe and the U.S. agree on what they don’t want — a future in which AI is used to build up an Orwellian surveillance apparatus — but they’re far from able to agree what they do want. “We’ll never apologize for wanting to have the use of technology in a way that is consistent with our values,” Parker told POLITICO over the phone from Paris. By joining ranks, she added, the West would be able to come up with “a good counter to what China is doing.” What she didn’t say at the time was that the White House was also ready to revisit the Franco-Canadian proposal from 2018. Four months later, in June 2020, the U.S. signed on to a tweaked version of the pitch, announcing that all G7 members (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the U.K. and the U.S.) plus Australia, South Korea, Singapore, Mexico, India, Slovenia and the EU would launch an alliance dubbed the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI) to support the “responsible and human-centric development and use” of AI. The idea was to do it “in a manner consistent with human rights, fundamental freedoms and our shared democratic values,” the countries added in a statement. In other words: a different approach from China’s. ‘Trustworthy’ versus ‘innovation’? As artificial intelligence changes societies around the world, this new GPAI alliance as well as the OECD have emerged as the key arenas for the U.S., Europe and other Western countries to join forces and come up with global standards for AI. But first, Europe and the U.S. need to see eye to eye, and that isn’t a given. They agree on what they don’t want — a future in which AI is used to build up an Orwellian surveillance apparatus — but they’re far from able to agree on what they do want. The EU, home of stringent privacy laws, wants to become a leader in “trustworthy” AI and plans to release the world’s first laws for AI early next year. This, Brussels hopes, will protect Europeans against abuse and boost consumer trust in European AI while giving its industry a competitive advantage in the long run. The U.S., on the other hand, considers Brussels’ approach “heavy-handed” and “innovation-killing,” echoing the position of its own tech industry, whose representatives have warned that too many rules would stifle innovation. In feedback to a first draft of Europe’s upcoming laws for AI, submitted to the EU in May, for instance, industry giant Google warned Brussels that too many new rules would “significantly weaken Europe’s position vis-a-vis global competitors.” The job of the new GPAI alliance, which will meet for the first time in December, will be to bring those two positions together. A platform called RadVid-19 that identifies lung injuries through artificial intelligence is helping Brazilian doctors detect and diagnose coronavirus | Nelson Almeida/AFP via Few details have been shared with the public about the partnership. But a series of conversations with officials and appointed members, conducted on the condition of anonymity because the work is confidential, suggests that it does not intend to work on any legal instruments. But its role will likely go beyond bringing top-notch AI scientists and policymakers to the same table — and could influence the OECD’s work on developing detailed AI principles, which in turn are meant to provide a framework for governments drafting hard laws. Corporation rules The work to form a Western alliance on AI comes as the technology is moving from the realm of science-fiction into everyday use. Today, AI is used to treat cancer , predict the outbreak of violent conflicts , analyze satellite data to monitor migration patterns , power military operations and even write news articles . But it also comes with significant risks, beyond being abused by governments to spy on their citizens: Most of today’s cutting-edge AI systems are, for example, prone to discriminate against vulnerable groups and minorities. This has led to text analysis software labeling being Jewish or being gay as negative, British students from poor areas being disadvantaged during exams, or a Black American being arrested for a crime he did not commit. Against this backdrop, organizations ranging from the Catholic Church to Big Tech corporations have all released nonbinding ethical principles for how to develop and use AI. While European leaders are eyeing laws as sweeping as the General Data Protection Regulation, the U.S. has been pushing a light-touch approach to regulation within its own borders. Yet these have not stopped companies and governments from rolling out invasive technology, including in privacy-conscious Europe, where law enforcement is now using facial-recognition technology with minimal public oversight. What rules do exist have largely been developed by industry players — such as Google, Facebook and Apple in the U.S., or Tencent and Alibaba in China — for themselves. “The rules for AI are, in effect, being written in code by the biggest tech companies who have the biggest AI research and the biggest pools of data and the biggest connection to a number of people who are the providers of data,” said Mark Surman, the executive director of the Mozilla Foundation. President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen at the AI Xperience Center of the VUB university in Brussels | Pool photo by Stephanie Lecocq via While policymakers have long been told by the industry that AI systems were black boxes whose inner workings were virtually impossible to understand, that argument is now falling on deaf ears. Joanna Bryson, a computer scientist and professor of ethics and technology at Berlin-based Hertie School, said that governments “are starting to understand that [the tech industry] is not that different from the pharma industry, or finance.” “When you start to understand that it’s all software … and someone chooses which algorithms to use, which data to use, what threshold of performance to achieve, you realize that those are all things you can check and regulate,” she added. Enter the OECD The hard part for governments will be to come up with the rules. While European leaders are eyeing laws as sweeping as the General Data Protection Regulation, the U.S. has been pushing a light-touch approach to regulation within its own borders. Even so, governments involved in GPAI acknowledge that to regulate the global AI industry, international rules are needed — rules that are often drafted in standard-setting bodies where China has been particularly active over the past decade. Beijing has notably been pushing its ideas inside the Internet Engineering Task Force, an international organization developing core protocols for the internet; and technical standard-setting bodies like the United Nations’ International Telecommunication Union, whose recommendations are often made policy by countries in the Global South. The new alliance will be governed by a council, which will meet annually at the OECD in Paris. “They really have made a big push over the last 10 years,” said Michael R. Nelson, who directs the technology and international affairs program at think tank Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. “They’ve also hired consultants to work with the companies to push their visions.” To counter these efforts, the West is seeking to build its own community, and seems to have found it at the OECD. In May 2019, the organization released its own broad guidelines for the use and deployment of AI, the first international agreement on AI endorsed by Trump’s White House. In addition — and with the White House’s blessing — the OECD in February launched an initiative to monitor and develop best practices in governing AI. It wasn’t until the spring of this year, when it became clear that the OECD would host the secretariat of the GPAI, that the U.S. decided to throw its weight behind the new alliance, according to officials involved in the negotiations. Bionic limbs displayed at the Amazon Re:MARS conference on robotics and artificial intelligence | Mark Ralston/AFP via “The U.S. decided to join because it was better to be inside the tent influencing its efforts than outside,” said Robert D. Atkinson, the president of the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation, a think tank whose board includes members of tech giants like Amazon or Google. The new alliance will be governed by a council, which will meet annually at the OECD in Paris. Apart from that, most details are still yet to be decided. What’s already become clear, however, is that finding a joint position won’t be easy. When members of one of the partnership’s four working groups met for a first confidential online meeting earlier this summer, it didn’t take long until participants from Europe and the U.S. started clashing over issues such as which players in the industry deserved the greatest support from policymakers, according to one participant. Want more analysis from POLITICO ? POLITICO Pro is our premium intelligence service for professionals. From financial services to trade, technology, cybersecurity and more, Pro delivers real time intelligence, deep insight and breaking scoops you need to keep one step ahead. Email pro@politico.eu to request a complimentary trial.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W8S-87K1-JBK9-2153-00000-00Was Googles 137-Milliarden-Imperium droht, wenn es den Kampf mit den Kartellbehörden verliert2019-06-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:59ZLexisNexisWas Googles 137-Milliarden-Imperium droht, wenn es den Kampf mit den Kartellbehörden verliertNick Bastone

Egal, ob US-Präsident Donald Trump oder die linke Demokratin Elizabeth Warren: Inzwischen glauben viele US-Politiker, dass Google zu mächtig geworden ist.

Aber wenn es darum geht, was gegen die Übermacht von Google getan werden kann, gibt es keine einfache Antwort.Der Internetgigant kontrolliert mehr als 37 Prozent des Online-Werbemarkts in den USA und mehr als 92 Prozent des Markts für Suchmaschinen. Für Deutschland dürften ähnliche Zahlen gelten. Dem Konzern gehört die weltweit größte Video-Plattform (Youtube) und er erstellt die Software für acht von zehn Smartphones weltweit. Diese Allgegenwart hat zu Aufrufen geführt, die Macht von Google einzudämmen.

Laut einem kürzlich im "Wall Street Journal" veröffentlichten Bericht bereitet das US-Justizministerium eine kartellrechtliche Untersuchung gegen Google vor.

In den USA erhielt Google bisher nur geringe Geldstrafen

Es ist noch unklar, auf welchen Teil von Googles Geschäft die Untersuchung des Justizministeriums abzielen wird, geschweige denn, welche Art von Sanktionen in Frage kämen. Angesichts der massiven und vielfältigen Geschäfte von Google - einschließlich der Tatsache, dass Google selbst Teil der größeren Holding Alphabet ist - kann das regulatorische Vorgehen eine Reihe von Folgen haben. Möglich wären zum Beispiel eine verstärkte Aufsicht, neue Beschränkungen für die Geschäftsausweitung und sogar eine Zerschlagung, wie sie derzeit auch bei Facebook diskutiert wird.

Die US-Ausgabe von Business Insider sprach mit mehreren Kartellexperten und Wall Street-Analysten, um sich ein Bild von den möglichen Auswirkungen und den Risiken für Google zu machen. Das Folgende könnte Google passieren, wenn festgestellt wird, dass es gegen die Kartellvorschriften verstößt.

Seit seiner Gründung vor zwei Jahrzehnten hatte Google die größten Probleme mit den staatlichen Aufsichtsbehörden in Form von Geldstrafen. In den USA wurde gegen Google eine Reihe von bescheidenen Bußgeldern für Verstöße gegen Datenschutzbestimmungen verhängt. In Europa waren die Strafen hingegen strenger: Die Europäische Kommission hat Google im Laufe der Jahre zu Geldstrafen in Höhe von insgesamt rund 10 Milliarden US-Dollar für verschiedene wettbewerbswidrige Praktiken verdonnert.

Experte "glaubt nicht, dass ein Bußgeld in Frage kommt"

Es steht zur Debatte, ob diese Sanktionen bei einem Unternehmen wirksam sind, dessen Bilanzsumme über 100 Milliarden US-Dollar liegt. Nach Ansicht vieler Experten, mit denen Business Insider gesprochen hat, steht dies jedoch diesmal kaum zur Diskussion.

"Ich glaube nicht, dass ein Bußgeld in Frage kommt", sagte Robert Lande, Rechtsprofessor der Universität Baltimore, zu Business Insider. Das liegt daran, dass das US-Justizministerium, wie Lande erklärte, keine Geldstrafe gegen Google erheben kann, es sei denn, das Unternehmen hat gegen eine bereits bestehende Vereinbarung verstoßen. Und bisher gibt es keine solche Vereinbarung zwischen Google und dem Justizministerium.

Ein weiterer Grund, warum sich Google keine Sorgen um hohe Bußgelder in den USA machen muss, ist die Art und Weise, in der die US-Aufsichtsbehörden den durch wettbewerbswidriges Verhalten verursachten Schaden im Vergleich zu dem in Europa beurteilen.

Das Vorgehen der EU bietet dem US-Justizministerium eine gute Vorlage

"Die EU konzentriert sich mehr auf die Schädigung von Wettbewerbern, während sich die USA auf die Schädigung von Verbrauchern konzentriert", sagt Michael Carrier, Rechtsprofessor an der Rutgers University. In einer Welt mit kostenlosen Webdiensten für Verbraucher - von Google Mail bis Android - ist es schwierig, die Schädigung von Verbrauchern zu begründen.

Doch das Vorgehen der EU jenseits des Atlantiks bietet eine gute Vorlage für die Teile von Googles Geschäft, die in das Hoheitsgebiet des US-Justizministeriums fallen. Insbesondere das Werbegeschäft von Google, das Geschäft mit den Suchmaschinen und die Android-Software haben sich als erfolgreiche Untersuchungsziele der EU-Behörden erwiesen.

"Ich würde damit anfangen, mich mit dem EU-Verfahren gegen Google zu befassen", sagte Carrier. "Hat Google bei der Suche seine eigenen Einkaufsdienste den Konkurrenten vorgezogen? Welche Auswirkung hatten Exklusivitätsklauseln auf Anzeigen? Und was ist bei Android mit der Bündelung von Google-Software mit Android?"

Frühere kartellrechtliche Untersuchung wurde als "leichter Klaps auf die Hand von Google" verspottet

Obwohl diese Bereiche vergangener Verstöße möglicherweise ein Ausgangspunkt für das Justizministerium sind, sagte eine Quelle auf dem Capitol Hill, die kürzlich mit Business Insider gesprochen hat, dass die Untersuchung wahrscheinlich offen dabei sein wird, "alles" über Google zu untersuchen.

Die große Frage ist, ob eine potenzielle Maßnahme des US-Justizministeriums gegen Google mehr Biss haben würde als die kartellrechtliche Untersuchung der Federal Trade Commission 2013 über die Geschäftspraktiken von Google in den Bereichen Suche und Smartphone.

Lest auch: Tesla, Amazon und Co.: Bei diesen 13 Unternehmen verdienen Praktikanten Tausende Dollar pro Monat

Google hat diese Begegnung ohne finanzielle Nachteile hinter sich gelassen und sich nur vagen Versprechungen verpflichtet, einige Geschäftspraktiken zu ändern, was von vielen Kritikern als ein "leichter Klaps auf die Hand von Google" verspottet wurde.

Die Macht der "Big Tech"-Unternehmen wird Thema im Wahlkampf 2020

In Anbetracht des aktuellen politischen Klimas und der Rhetorik, mit der "Big Tech" zerschlagen werden soll, wird es diesmal vielleicht anders sein. Zum ersten Mal seit dem frühen 20. Jahrhundert ist die Konzentration der Macht der Unternehmen ein wichtiges Thema bei den anstehenden Präsidentschaftswahlen in den USA.

Bekannte Politiker - wie die Präsidentschaftskandidatin Elizabeth Warren - forderten eine Zerschlagung der wichtigsten Akteure der Technologiebranche, darunter Google, Apple, Facebook und Amazon. Im Fall von Google sagte Warren, um den Suchgiganten "abzuwickeln", würde sie damit beginnen, dass das Unternehmen größere Zukäufe wie den Kartendienst Waze, das Smart-Home-Hardware-Unternehmen Nest und die Werbeplattform DoubleClick veräußern muss.

Das ist vielleicht leichter gesagt als getan. Mehrere Kartellexperten, die diese Woche mit Business Insider gesprochen haben, sagten, die Wahrscheinlichkeit einer Zerschlagung sei gering.

Zerschlagung von Google ist kaum möglich

"Es ist sehr schwierig, frühere Zukäufe rückgängig zu machen", sagte Carrier von der Rutgers University. "Die Unternehmen sind verschmolzen und die Bestandteile lassen sich nicht mehr voneinander trennen."

So wurde das Smart-Home-Unternehmen Nest, das 2014 von Google übernommen wurde, nun vollständig in den Hardwarebereich des Unternehmens aufgenommen. Im Mai kündigte das Unternehmen auf der diesjährigen I / O-Entwicklerkonferenz an, dass das Branding für seine Smart-Home-Produkte jetzt "Google Nest" lauten wird, wie in "Google Nest Learning Thermostat" und "Google Nest Secure Alarm".

Lest auch: Diese 20 Unternehmen beherrschen das Internet in Deutschland

Blockaden zwischen dem ehemaligen Nest-Team und Googles eigener Hardware-Abteilung sind ebenfalls verschwunden, teilte Rishi Chandra, Vizepräsident des Nest-Produktmanagements Business Insider kürzlich in einem Interview mit: "Es ist jetzt ein Team. Eine Roadmap für die gesamte Organisation."

Aufgrund der Schwierigkeiten, die mit einer echten Zerschlagung einhergingen, sagten Experten, dass ein plausibleres Ergebnis für die Untersuchung des Justizministeriums die Blockierung zukünftiger Geschäfte für Google sei. Und für den Technologieriesen könnte dies ein potenzielles Risiko darstellen.

Das Verbot von Zukäufen könnte Googles Cloud-Dienst schmerzlich treffen

"[Das Justizministerium] kann Zukäufe natürlich blockieren", sagte Michael Pachter, Manager bei Wedbush Securities, zu Business Insider diese Woche. " bezweifle, dass es viele Unternehmen gibt, die Google kaufen 'muss' ... [Aber] das Blockieren zukünftiger Käufe ist immer ein Risiko für jedes große Unternehmen."

Auf die Frage, wo es Google am meisten weh tue, wenn das US-Justizministerium sich für eine Strategie der Blockade statt einer Zerschlagung entscheidet, sieht Dan Ives, ebenfalls Manager bei Wedbush Securities, am ehesten das Cloud-Computing-Geschäft des Unternehmens betroffen. Die Google Cloud Platform (GCP) rangiert heute auf dem Markt abgeschlagen auf Platz drei hinter Amazon Web Services und Microsoft Azure.

"Das Hauptproblem hierbei ist, ob dies den Fokus von Google auf Zukäufe im Zusammenhang mit der GCP einschränkt", sagte Ives. "Als [Thomas] Kurian zu Google kam, war dies der Trommelwirbel für viel wichtigere Transaktionen im Cloud-Bereich."

Untersuchung wirft ihre Schatten auf Google

Kurian wurde im Januar als Cloud-Chef von Google engagiert und löste Diane Greene ab. Nach 22 Jahren bei Oracle sollte Kurian das Cloud-Geschäft des Unternehmens im Wettbewerb mit Unternehmen wie Amazon und Microsoft unterstützen. Analysten gehen davon aus, dass ein Teil der Aufholung auf dem Cloud-Markt durch Fusionen und Übernahmen erfolgen könnte.

Jetzt sagte Ives, dass das Potenzial der Untersuchung des Justizministeriums Google möglicherweise vor einer aggressiveren Zukaufstrategie zurückschreckt, selbst wenn eine solche Auflage gar nicht erhoben wird.

"Es fühlt sich an, als würden die Flügel von den Schatten der kartellrechtlichen Ermittlungen beschnitten", sagte Ives. "Es würde mich wundern, wenn sie sich aggressiv um Fusionen und Übernahmen bemühen würden, jetzt wo sie im Rampenlicht stehen."

urn:contentItem:5X7M-RVV1-JB20-G116-00000-00Washington and Beijing Holding High Level Talks Today; Record Numbers of Schools Ending SAT, ACT Requirement; Facebook CEO to Testify Before House on Libra; Sully Receives Public Service Award; Waze Connects Users for an Affordable Commute2019-10-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:59ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTDennis Gartman, Noam Bardin, Veronica DagherNEWSFinancial101002cb.231Washington and Beijing Holding High Level Talks Today; Record Numbers of Schools Ending SAT, ACT Requirement; Facebook CEO to Testify Before House on Libra; Sully Receives Public Service Award; Waze Connects Users for an Affordable CommuteMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, James Freeman, Newt Gingrich, Lauren Simonetti, Deirdre Bolton

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, October 10th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

U.S.-China trade focus today. Big story as investors await any details out of these high level talks that are getting under way this morning in Washington. The U.S. also could be easing some restrictions on Huawei. We've got that for you.

There was a lot of volatility in markets overnight after there was a report that the Chinese delegation would be leaving today and then saying no, we're leaving Friday.

Ahead of the talks, futures showing the markets are lower this morning. We're expecting a decline at the start of trading -- fractional move after a big gain yesterday on the hopes of at least partial trade deal.

Dow Industrials finished off 182 points at the close yesterday, three- quarters of 1 percent. The S&P was up 26. And the Nasdaq up 80 points, better than 1 percent.

Global markets this morning look like this. European indices are mixed. FT 100 down 9. CAC 40 in Paris up 17. And the DAX index in Germany lower by 2 points. And the economic data driving stories there.

In Asia overnight, markets are mostly higher with the Korean KOSPI index bucking the trend, lower after a holiday the day before -- fractional moves across the board there.

China continues a full court press on the NBA. An exhibition game still scheduled to tip off in about half an hour. It's happening in shanghai this morning but it will not be seen on televisions in China.

Other related events were canceled and Chinese businesses continue to pull away from the league.

Also off the air there -- "South Park" but that doesn't stop the show from taking a swipe at China last night.

Plus, Apple removes a controversial app that tracks police activity in Hong Kong citing safety reasons. Companies are caving in to China's demands.

Facebook's other social media brands, meanwhile -- a new poll shows most people do not even realize they're using apps owned by Facebook. The numbers coming up.

All those stores coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business' Dagen McDowell. The "Wall Street Journal's" wealth management reporter. She's the host of the podcast, "Secrets of Wealthy Women" -- Veronica Dagher. And the assistant editorial page editor at the "Wall Street Journal" -- James Freeman.

Lots to talk about this morning.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Yes. I hope if President Trump doesn't get a deal soon with China. I hope he moves quickly to make trade peace with all of our friends around the world.

The Japan deal is a good template. I would say if you're going to play this out with China, you need a reason to give people to invest and other trade deals would be very helpful.

BARTIROMO: You want something like TPP.

FREEMAN: That that would be nice.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: I know you don't -- you can't call it that. So, you know, new plan but you did it with japan, how about every other country, offer them the same deal and try to get that done and then, you know, you've got leverage to play it out with China. We'll see where it goes.

BARTIROMO: And then there's Brexit. You have to believe that once Brexit does happen, if it happens, he'll move aggressively to do a deal with the U.K.

FREEMAN: That would help too. And of course, the Congress can help by passing the USMCA with Canada and Mexico. Maybe they will --

BARTIROMO: Well, that's up to Nancy Pelosi.

FREEMAN: Yes. But she might -- there might be an incentive to show they're not just the impeachment Congress.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That they actually care about the American people? Really? Ok.

BARTIROMO: We'll see. We'll see.

Right now it's all about taking down the President.

VERONICA DAGHER, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": And what kind of trade deal are we going to get? I'm just curious though, right? Is it going to be a skinny deal that some people are speaking about? Because if we get that skinny deal, I just wonder, to your point from before, how much is that really going to move the market in the long term?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I don't know that that's going to be all that positive. Maybe we get a rally on news of a skinny deal. We'll see.

But that push for impeachment is certainly top of news. Supporting the impeachment of President Trump reaching a record high, apparently. According to a new Fox News poll, the majority of voters say that they want President Trump impeached and removed from office. That's up 9 points from July.

Former vice president Joe Biden officially backing calls for the push. The 2020 hopeful trading barbs with President Trump yesterday. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Donald Trump has violated his oath of office, betrayed this nation and committed impeachable acts. To preserve our constitution, our democracy, our basic integrity, he should be impeached.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I don't think he's going to make it. I didn't think he was going to make it for a long time. I don't think he's going to make it.

And I guess this is one way he could do it. He didn't say that until right now and he sees what's happening to him. I guess he's no longer the frontrunner.

And he's been caught red-handed. I mean here's a man who is on tape saying exactly what he's going to do in terms of corruption and he gets away with it. If that ever happened to a Republican, they'd be getting the electric chair right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Fox News contributor, former House Speaker and "Trump versus China" author, Newt Gingrich. Mr. Speaker -- it's always a pleasure. Thanks for joining us -- Newt.

NEWT GINGRICH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It's good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: What do you make of these polls that say 51 percent of people would like to see the impeachment? Are you buying this?

GINGRICH: Look, I think if you have week after week of the "New York Times" and "Washington Post" and all the major networks giving their version of reality, it has an effect. Does it mean that Trump's going to lose the election? No. Does it mean he's going to be impeached? No.

But a lot of this is just the sheer weight of unbelievably biased coverage and the fact that the Democrats have been playing a game. The fact is, for example, you have a guy who is a leaker who we call a whistleblower because that sounds so much nicer, he didn't blow a whistle on anything. He didn't witness anything.

It's now turning out he's a Democrat. He may well have actually worked with some of the Democratic presidential candidates. But all of this takes a while.

And we've seen this three or four times now. We saw it with Judge Kavanaugh.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GINGRICH: We saw it earlier with the Russian collusion. You know, the news media comes in, creates a totally biased story. For a brief period the country goes well, if that's true, then of course you're right. And then they begin to go yes, but it's not true. And then gradually we get back to where we were.

So my guess is in a week or two Trump will be back at about where he's been all along which is 45 percent support and considering that he probably is at 5 to 8 percent above that, just because people in this kind of environment, people won't tell you they're for Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GINGRICH: Because the social pressure's so great.

BARTIROMO: So are you -- do you agree with the White House's move to say I'm not going to cooperate with the impeachment measures because it's an impeachment show. They need to take the floor --

GINGRICH: You know look, this --

BARTIROMO: -- let me just show you this editorial piece in the "Journal" this morning. You've seen it this morning, "Back to you, Nancy". The editorial board of the "Wall Street Journal" writes this. "No one should be surprised if the White House chooses to fight back and hard when Democrats are trying to remove Mr. Trump from office and brand him as impeached for 2020. The Pelosi Democrats are fighting ugly and Mr. Trump is fighting ugly back."

This is what I find really interesting because the Democrats always fight ugly. They're not afraid to get in the mud. That's just been who -- that's who they are, that's been the case for years.

They haven't met a guy like Mr. Trump who says you know what, yes, let's get in the mud, I'm ready for it and fights back the way he does. They don't like it.

GINGRICH: That's right. That's how he won the presidency. If he hadn't been prepared to match Hillary and to stay slugging it out, he wouldn't have become president. So it shouldn't surprise us any.

This is not an impeachment. I mean I'm going to make this very clear. This is a coup. The first left wing gathering of the crisis level was on the ninth on November, 2016 -- the day after the election. They had gatherings in eight or nine cities.

By the middle of December of that year, "Vanity Fair" had an article on the movement to impeach Trump. By the day of the inaugural, the "Washington Post" -- literally, the day of the inaugural, the "Washington Post" had a story that the move to impeach Trump was underway and the following day of course you had a huge series of rallies against Trump all over the country, the day after he's sworn in.

So this shouldn't surprise anybody. The left hates Trump, that includes the "New York Times" and the "Washington Post". They're going to do everything they can to destroy him. They can't -- they're afraid he'll win the next election so they're trying to find somebody.

But in the end, it's pretty stupid. I mean, you know, Nancy Pelosi can't even play tic tac toe. She can't figure out that there's a second step.

For example, this guy who they're keeping secret, well, if they do pass impeachment, it goes to the Senate. And Lindsey Graham, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, has already said the minute it gets to the Senate, he's having this guy in under oath and public.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GINGRICH: So they haven't thought through that. Act two is the Republicans in the Senate. They're going to ask Hunter Biden what did you do for $600,000 a year.

MCDOWELL: Newt -- it's Dagen McDowell. It looks like that the Democrats are trying to trip up the President or set up the President, if you will. And trick him into doing something they could then say oh, obstruction of Congress -- you've actually heard them say that. We're going to now impeach him for obstruction of Congress when he wasn't actually doing anything to obstruct an impeachment proceeding that actually isn't an impeachment proceeding because they haven't voted on it yet.

Again, if you read the -- if you read every word in some of these newspaper articles, not the "Wall Street Journal", and they will say, well, one of the articles of impeachment under Richard Nixon was failure to provide information to Congress related to the inquiry. So you see where they're going here.

GINGRICH: Sure. But let's start with -- you know, a reporter said the other day that Speaker Pelosi -- what if this doesn't work out and this guy doesn't stand up. And her answer was oh, we have many candidates for impeachment. This is just the easiest one to explain.

I mean this is all a game. And that's why it's not an impeachment. It's a coup. It has nothing to do with the constitutional concept of impeachment which is for high crimes and -- it has nothing to do with that.

This has to do with left wing Democrats who can't stand the idea that the American people gave the White House to somebody who clearly violates all of their norms and actually behaves as though he's a conservative and he's the most aggressive anti-liberal in my lifetime and it drives them crazy. So I don't think they can control themselves.

Part two of this is not Trump leaving Washington. Part two is if they have the nerve -- I said openly, you can always impeach if you have a majority if you're prepared to commit suicide.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GINGRICH: Nancy Pelosi forces all of her moderate and red district Democrats to vote yes on impeachment. Collin Peterson's a good example, he's in a Minnesota district that was 30 points for Trump.

Now how is he going to vote yes in impeachment and run for reelection. And so if she's prepared to become the minority leader again, they can get the patient to the House then it goes to the Senate where I think they get ripped to shreds.

And I think you get Biden brought in and they say were you not aware that your son was making $600,000 a year. I mean, does anybody in America believe that my two daughters could be making $600,000 a year and I wouldn't know it?

BARTIROMO: $600,000 a year.

GINGRICH: And that's the Biden current claim.

BARTIROMO: From Ukraine? Wow.

GINGRICH: from one company. Just from Ukraine. That doesn't count whatever else he was making.

BARTIROMO: I didn't realize it was $600,000.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: ok. Newt -- thank you.

GINGRICH: I cheated. It's $50,000 a month times 12 so $600,000 a year.

MCDOWELL: Which is roughly double what an ExxonMobil board member makes.

ExxonMobil board member in the most recent fiscal year made about [$300,000] on average, $330,000, so Hunter Biden whose work experience was being on the board of Amtrak was making 600 grand a year.

FREEMAN: Are you saying that Burisma is no ExxonMobil?

GINGRICH: Wait a second. It's totally legitimate for Biden to be on the Amtrak board because Joe went back and forth to Wilmington on Amtrak all the time. They had a lot of knowledge about Amtrak.

I would like to know, other than maybe reading Wikipedia, what did Hunter know about anything involving Ukrainian national gas company?

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

Well, similar story in China where, you know, the money was big there. The $1 billion which turned into $1.5 billion after his trip with his father on Air Force 2. Newt, thank you. Good to see you, sir.

GINGRICH: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Newt Gingrich there.

While we were talking Delta Airlines reported earnings.

Lauren Simonetti with the numbers now -- Lauren.

SIMONETTI: Yes. The stock not liking what came out in terms of earnings. As you can see, it's down 0.8 percent. This is the second best airline carrier of the year.

Ok. So earnings per share were better than expected, $2.32 a share versus the estimate of $2.26. But a miss by a little bit when it came to revenue. Coming in at $12.56 billion.

Investors are concerned about what is going forward for Delta. Their guidance was very light for the all-important holiday quarter. That's the fourth quarter. They guided in a range of $1.20, to $1.50 when the (INAUDIBLE) estimate is $1.51. so much lower there.

And then you have to remember. They don't fly -- and this a good thing for them -- the 737 Max jet that's been under fire but when that returns, they might be affected by pricing from other airlines. So those are some head winds affecting the company, especially an economic slowdown on an international level that could affect them going forward.

Back to you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Lauren. Stock is down better than 1 percent. We've got a big show this morning. Don't miss it. The "Gartman Letter" editor and publisher Dennis Gartman is coming up.

To talk markets and China. The CEO of Waze, Noam Bardin is here. The company marking one year since its carpool service debut and Google partnership. And then the former senior advisor to President George W. Bush, Fox News contributor Karl Rove joining us to talk impeachment and his "Wall Street Journal" op-ed ed today. House Financial services committee member. Congressman Lance Gooden is here and the CEO of Sanders -- Francis David Savin talks short-term rentals and hotel industry, similar to Air BNB but not really. We'll tell you about.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, two British ISIS prisoners now in custody in the U.S. Cheryl Casone with the details -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well Maria -- the two ISIS fighters tied to the notorious British terror cell, the Beatles, they are the only two ISIS fighters removed from removed from Syria by the U.S. so far but officials say, there could be more thousands of others remain in custody under Kurdish control as of now.

Well, when it comes to social media business in particular -- American Cinderella come up short and their knowledge. According a new Pew Center of Survey. Just 29 percent of us know that Instagram and What's App are owned by Facebook.

Over all less than half of those asked knew the answers to a digital knowledge quiz but there's Facebook in the pre-market, down slightly.

Ok.

And then I love this story -- Maria. Uber is now letting your pets come along for the ride. They're now letting passengers bring along their furry friends to reduce cancellations. Surprised pets, believe it or not, are one of drivers' biggest complaints. The new program is going to be available in select cities. That starts on October 16th.

Because don't discriminate against my dog or my cat. Come on now.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: It's ridiculous.

Yes. Drivers were flipping out about it. Well, too bad.

MCDOWELL: Let me point out, if you've got a fluffy little nugget like a Charlie or a Dusty that can sit in your lap, that's a big difference than a Slob-o-pus who gets in your car and starts shedding everywhere.

(CROSSTALKING)

MCDOWELL: Like a bloodhound.

BARTIROMO: That's the same thing as traveling with your dog on an airplane, right?

MCDOWELL: Airplanes have become a nightmare though.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But I mean you can't have that kind of a big dog on a plane.

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: That's what I'm saying. If you have a small dog, it's ok, it doesn't cause too much disruption, what's the problem?

MCDOWELL: But now if you have the dog, if you put it in a crate and pay $125, $150 per trip for a dog, put it under the seat like luggage. But if you have the dog out, you have to -- they've really cracked down on emotional support certificates for people. And so even if you take your dog out of the crate, they lose their business.

And people -- it's not just an Uber driver. It's all the other people on the plane where some individuals like to make up that they have dog allergies.

BARTIROMO: I think they're making -- I agree with you.

MCDOWELL: Ma'am, if you have a dog allergy, you need to tell the airline in advance.

BARTIROMO: I told the airline in advance that Charlie would be here -- period.

MCDOWELL: Right. I have my -- yes. I drive now.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Then you've got Charlie right there in the car.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Apple is under pressure this morning. The technology giant removes a controversial app that tracks police activity in Hong Kong. The reason they removed it -- are they caving like others? We'll take a look.

Then testing optional, a growing number of colleges remove standardized test requirements.

Back in a minute with that.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

American companies eager to reach China's 1.4 billion people are now facing censorship hurdles.

Deirdre Bolton is covering the story this morning. And it is getting wider and wider and wider.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: It sure is. And Apple is the latest one. They removed the HKMap.live app from its app store. And the "People's Daily" had actually criticized Apple saying that they had not -- I'm quoting here, "The People's Daily, obviously state-run media -- Apple had not hidden their malicious motive in providing navigation for the riders.

Apple -- and this is coming from Apple, this is their statement. The App has been used in ways that endangers law enforcement and residents. So they're basically saying both sides are finding out where these protesters are showing up and it's just augmenting a very tense situation.

But Apple was clear to us in its statement, in its response saying, "We pulled this app because of safety concerns, not political concerns," because of course the larger conversation we've been having with these U.S. big brands, I mean whether it's the NBA or Activision Blizzard or Vans sneakers or Tiffany's is that U.S. companies are caving.

The one thing I will say about big tech functioning on mainland China -- is that it's really two companies that we would know the name of. It's basically Apple and Microsoft. Both of those companies over the years have at least agreed to play -- if they're not playing ball with the Chinese state, they're at least playing a few innings.

Google is not there. Google started to do some work called Dragon Fly. It was going to be a search engine over there but its own employees really just raised such a fuss that the company ended up killing it.

Facebook we know really tried to be there. I mean Mark Zuckerberg was teaching himself Mandarin. He was going over. He was courting officials. It just didn't work out.

And then eventually this spring Mark Zuckerberg said something like, kind of like it was a bit of sour grapes. Let's hear it from the cynical perspective, well, we didn't really want to be there anyway.

But both Apple and Microsoft have found a way, love it or hate it, to actually work within the system. I just want to quote one of the people from Apple. It's policy chief saying that censoring for the Chinese government, so Apple is there, they know that censorship happens, but she says encourages greater overall freedoms and that it facilitates the free flow of ideas and information.

Now, there are a lot of people who call absolute nonsense on that quote and they say look, Apple just has so much of a presence there and a footprint there, that it is in their best interest to get along.

But more recently Apple has removed pro democracy songs by Hong Kong singers from the Chinese music store. It did remove Taiwan's flag from the emoji library. And as we know, I mean Taiwan and China have been governed for decades separately but the idea of the Communist manifesto is for reunification and then with this latest salvo is this hot maps in Hong Kong.

Microsoft we know, bought LinkedIn and they have LinkedIn up and running there. And they say well, we can't really pull out of China with LinkedIn because then that deprives the Chinese people of looking for their hopes and dreams.

As they said, maybe not willing to play ball, Apple and Microsoft, but they're certainly willing to play a few innings.

MCDOWELL: What was the statement again? We need to impose censorship in order to promote free speech?

BOLTON: That's from Apple. Yes, that's Apple.

MCDOWELL: Can you believe what it sounds like? It's like censorship somehow --

BOLTON: You remember this when Apple agreed to let some data centers be on the mainland and people went absolutely bananas about that. And that's the response as you said. I know. It sounds.

When you read it, you're just like --

BARTIROMO: You know I would like to see it. I'd like to hear from right now, the Business Roundtable, right.

The Business Roundtable said that they want to put profits second or third after the other stakeholders, employees and the communities they operate in. What does the Business Roundtable have to say about China's behavior?

DAGHER: Well, just as you allude to the statistics, 1.4 million inhabitants in China.

BARTIROMO: 1.4 billion.

(CROSSTALKING)

DAGHER: Yes, exactly -- billion.

MCDOWELL: That's them kowtowing to a different communist.

FREEMAN: The community should be worried about those -- the stakeholders. I also -- I wonder about these Silicon Valley people, who tell us how much they care about civil liberties, the Activision employees were -- some of them were demonstrating --

BOLTON: Yes. Because they stripped that young man of his gaming title and actually his prize money because he did make a statement on a streaming service in support of the Hong Kong pro democracy protesters.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, Google did not want to be evil so they walked away from the Pentagon. But they set up shop for their A.I.

(CROSSTALKING)

BOLTON: So actually to me, that's actually the bigger problem I think going forward is that we depend, happily or unhappily, on companies like Google to develop our next generation of A.I. And so if we're not letting that happen, or Google's employees are blocking that, then you can make an argument we're at a disadvantage versus the Chinese when it comes to this kind of technology.

BARTIROMO: Companies are waking up to this and you have to thank not just President Trump but Secretary Pompeo. He's done a great job in speaking to businesses about the national security issues around that.

BOLTON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Deirdre -- thank you.

BOLTON: Sure. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon.

Coming up markets are watching all of these developments. U.S. and Chinese officials meeting later this morning, the expectations coming up.

Markets have worsened in the last hour, down 58 points on the Dow Industrials now.

Then this crypto warning, an Apple co-founder speaks out about regulating digital currency, his comments right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Our top story this half an hour, the U.S.-China trade situation, the two sides are holding high level negotiations this morning in Washington ahead of increased U.S. tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods coming into this country, that is set to go into effect October 15th. There was a lot of volatility in the markets overnight after a report said that the Chinese delegation would be leaving today. The White House said that it has no knowledge of any news that it would be leaving early.

Joining us right now is The Gartman Letter editor and publisher, Dennis Gartman. And Dennis, it is good to see you this morning. Thanks for being here.

DENNIS GARTMAN, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER, THE GARTMAN LETTER: Thanks for having me. You guys scraped the bottom of the barrel and there I am.

BARTIROMO: So -- what? Not true, Dennis. But tell me this, how are you investing and what do you see about this China story that is actually dictating how you allocate capital and look at these markets.

GARTMAN: Well, first of all, I have only my own money at risk, it's my few million source, very -- it's sacrosanct and what I talked about in my newsletter I do. And for the first time in quite some long while I'm actually getting modestly and I mean, the operative word here is modestly net short.

I'm a little concerned about how quickly things sold off last night on the mere rumor and a rumor of a rumor that the Sherpas had not been able to reach and sort of an agreement and that there would be a delay or even an early leaving by the senior Chinese delegation.

So the fact that you were able to give up almost 400 Dow points in the course of a half an hour, tells me that underneath here there's nothing but thin air. So you have to be very careful. I think that the -- I keep in my own index called the international index of the 10 largest stock markets in the world and it made its high last January, January 29th actually of 19 -- 2018, we have not come anywhere close to being -- to making new highs. And so we've actually been in an international bear market for almost a year and-a-half. Let's be careful.

FREEMAN: OK, so given that the downer for the markets, the trade fights have been and now the president facing possible impeachment, do you think he now gets a deal? Is there -- is it a necessity for him and how do the markets react?

GARTMAN: I think it's an -- James, I think it's a necessity for both presidents, for Xi and for Trump to get some sort of a deal. It's going to be what's the term now, a skinny deal, it won't be a broad and expansive deal, we won't probably be able to get intellectual property rights taken care of. We'll probably not be able to get infrastructure. We'll probably not be able to get a broader representation. We'll get some soybeans sold. We might even get some corn sold. But will there be anything broad and expansive? Sadly, probably not. Will the Chinese give us promises that they won't keep? Probably so. And sadly, that's just the history of these sorts of agreements.

So it will be less than anybody hoped for (INAUDIBLE). And we'll probably have to wait until after the next election to get an expansive trade agreement signed between both countries.

DAGHER: Dennis, what percentage of your portfolio now is in cash and have you increased that and also, what's your read on precious metals like gold?

GARTMAN: Well, first of all, I'm quite bullish of the precious metals -- I've been bullish of gold for quite some period of time. I'd really like to see gold get above 15 20, that will be a breakout to the upside and I'll add to my gold position. Gold is probably 30 or 40 percent of what I own which is probably a little too much for the average American to have. But I'm quick to take losses, I'm quick to get out if something should turns against me.

As far as cash is concerned, the rest of my stuff is in bonds, corporate debt and I hedge it with derivatives. So actually if you want to say cash, I'm probably a hundred percent cash because I'm not -- I'm equally net long and net short, my net exposure to the stock market is relatively minimal at best.

BARTIROMO: So we're heading into the third quarter earnings reporting season, are there anything in the charts that you see that indicate performance ahead? I know you look at technical in terms of charts.

GARTMAN: Yes, I look at technical rather substantively. And it bothers me that if you look at the Dow, if you look at the S&P, if you look at the Russell two -- 5000 or whatever. Well, almost whatever index you look at, you're getting what the technicians call a head and shoulders top which is formed over the course of the past several months.

But more importantly as I said earlier, the fact that my international index has refused to make a new high since January of 2018 tells me that the internals are starting to turn down.

And I watch the CNN, and I hate to put in a plug for another network but the CNN Fear and Greed Index is a really good index for the average American to take a look at. And it has been making consistently lower highs and lower lows and it's turning quite bearish.

So I just think that one should be -- should be careful. Pros can be quietly modestly just a tad net short. The average investor should be -- it's still a bull market for him. He should be less long than he's been however.

But for the pros, being short is not such a bad idea right here and I'm short marginally. And the operative word here is marginally. Remember, this is my own money at risk.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Dennis, it's Dagen McDowell. Have you done any work on market reactions to impeachment proceedings?

GARTMAN: Well, having lived through two impeachment proceed -- well, actually --

MCDOWELL: That's why I asked you, my friend.

GARTMAN: It's not pretty. The -- what happened during the Nixon impeachment which never really got to impeachment itself was terrible. The Dow fell from a thousand six to 474 over the course of that what, 18 months of the entire impeachment proceedings.

During the -- during the Clinton proceed -- impeachment, the market actually didn't do very badly at all but I continue to remember how long it dragged out in the Nixon affair. And this seems more like the Nixon affair than it does the Clinton affair.

So quite honestly, there's nothing good that comes out of it. The best that you can say is that things won't get bad. The worst that you can say is things can get terrible.

BARTIROMO: Any thoughts on the Fed cutting rates in a week and-a-half or two weeks and what about the earnings period? What are you expecting?

GARTMAN: If I were the -- if I were a voter on the Fed, I would probably vote not to cut rates. I think however, that there's probably going to be a slight majority for cutting rates. Certainly we'll probably get a 25 basis point cut before the end of the year. The question shall be, will we get 25 in the next week and 25 in December --

BARTIROMO: We got the minutes yesterday -- we got the minutes from the September meeting yesterday when the central bank approved the quarter point reduction. And those minutes showed that investors are expecting the rate cut. But there's real division within the Fed.

GARTMAN: And I don't mind that. I don't mind having the Fed arguing one with the other. That doesn't -- that doesn't bother me even much at all. But the fact was, there's a great deal of dissension. The beige book was relatively inconsequential. The minutes were terribly inconsequential.

And I'm not -- I don't find it detrimental to find divisions within the FOMC. In fact, I rather like it. It shows they have -- we have individuals looking at their own data and making a decision and I think that the Fed chairman will do a fine job of keeping -- making -- finding some sort of consensus.

Do I think that they'll end up cutting rates? Yes, I do. 25 basis points. But as I said, if I were the -- if I were on the FOMC, I'd be a dissenter and vote no.

BARTIROMO: All right, Dennis, great to talk with you. Thank you so much.

GARTMAN: Thanks, Maria. Good to be on your show.

BARTIROMO: And to you, Dennis Gartman joining us there.

Coming up, standardize test, sigh of relief. More colleges ditching the traditional requirement.

Plus, navigating the competition, the CEO of Waze weighing in on how his company is racing to catch Uber and Lyft. That's coming up. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Major changes to college acceptances following the massive college admissions scandal. Cheryl Casone with headlines now, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Probably this was coming, Maria. A growing number of colleges are no longer looking for SAT and ACT test scores. One in four schools have now dropped the admission requirement in the wake of the Varsity Blues scandal. And this is happening as the ACT has announced students who have already taken the entire exam can retake specific sections, instead of taking it all over again.

Facebook's CEO soon going to be back on the hot seat in Washington. Mark Zuckerberg is going to be returning to Capitol Hill October 23rd to testify before a House panel about the Libra cryptocurrency project.

Now, the proposal has been sharply criticized by lawmakers in the U.S. and actually around the world after a string of privacy lapses at Facebook.

Steve Wozniak speaking out about government regulation of cryptocurrencies by the way. According to the Bloomberg, the Apple co-founder says countries will only want control as digital currencies grow in popularity.

And then Maria, you're going to love this one. Sully, former President George H. W. Bush's service dog has received the Public Service Award from the ASPCA. It is given to an animal or officer who demonstrates a commitment to their career. Sully was at the former president's side from 2018 until his death and actually beyond, as you can see by the casket there.

Sully now serves injured veterans and their families, Maria. We've talked about this before. He's working and I think very hard at Walter Reed Medical Center.

BARTIROMO: That's a beautiful story.

CASONE: I love Sully.

BARTIROMO: Beautiful. Thanks, Cheryl.

MCDOWELL: So I have a service dog story really quickly. Jennifer Williams who was Dana Perino's producer here, she trained a service dog, Spike, in the building. And now he's in like doggy college. But she works with Canine Companions, CCI Canine and one of the new puppies is named after Tyrus. They named a puppy after Tyrus. I think that was Dana's doing.

But again, if you follow CCI Canines, any of the service dog organizations that raise these animals for veterans and other people in need, it's really -- they're really uplifting stories. Better than Ellen and G -- and G. W. Bush having a little love fest. Dogs are much better than humans.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

FREEMAN: Also, he got into doggy college on the merits, there was no corruption.

DAGHER: That's right.

FREEMAN: Blaming that -- blaming the SAT and the ACT is absolutely the worst response here. I understand why colleges don't want to face the corruption inside their institutions, they want to point the just but this is the benchmark and if you need to work on security to make sure someone actually took the test, that's fine. But this is how you get away from all of this insider connections stuff is you have a benchmark everyone has to meet.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely.

MCDOWELL: Wake Forest where I went and where one of your children goes, Wake Forest though waived the requirement a while ago. There are a lot of universities that don't require you to take the test.

FREEMAN: They should bring it back.

BARTIROMO: Quick break and then competing with Uber and Lyft, I'll be speaking with the Waze CEO next. The company is facing some stiff competition but it's doing well. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Waze, the popular app that helps users report and avoid traffic in real-time has for the past year been creating car pools across the country and across the world.

My next guest knows all about that and dealing with the competition. Joining me right now is the CEO of Waze, Noam Bardin. Noam, it's great to have you on the program this morning. Thank you so much for being here.

NOAM BARDIN, CEO, WAZE: Thank you for having me. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations to you, I love the app. I know that people love it who drive and use it. So it's certainly been real successful even though you've got competition left and right. Tell us about the evolution and growth of Waze and how many users you have today?

BARDIN: So Waze is always an about improving your daily commute and traffic. And traffic really is the ill of modern life. I mean, it's terrible for your health, it's terrible for the economy, it's terrible globally, 30 percent of the emissions come from traffic.

And that was our mission from day one. And we started by optimizing existing infrastructure, right. Those short cuts that we used to find you with Waze and still are kind of known for are also a way of using more roads that up and now have not been used, right.

So we've finished optimizing the roads and now the second phase of our business, we're moving into carpooling. We're looking into your car. You've got four empty seats in your car. 75 percent of Americans commute alone. And so by allowing some of our drivers to leave their car at home once or twice a week and finding another driver who lives close to them, works close to them and allows them to take that ride, we can actually take cars off the road.

And this is crucial because, yes, we all feel that traffic's getting worse. It is. Like we see it statistically. It's getting worse, what you're feeling is right. And no one's coming to save us. I mean, the government's not going to save us. Technology's not going to save us. We need to do something about this because we are traffic and we really are the problem.

BARTIROMO: So are you up to 120 million users across the world? Tell us about the growth that you've seen, first off, since being acquired by Google. Just in that short period of time.

BARDIN: So it's interesting. When we started talking to Google about the acquisition, we were doing 10 million active Wazers a month. Today we're about 130, we'll probably end the year around 140 million active Wazers globally. And so, we've seen huge growth since we joined Google and in general. And this is really kind of that special love that we have. People when they talk about Waze, they get a little smile on it because we really help them in one of their worst part of their day.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because when you say active users, those people who are using the app but also contributing to it. You see a police car, you're putting that in. You see an accident, you're putting that in. The users are part of the experience.

But tell me how you separate from Google Maps because I know that Google recently updated Google Maps with live -- with the live camera. A lot of people say Waze and Google Maps are a buried treasure for Alphabet. But how do you differentiate from Google Maps? Is it -- is it -- is that a partner or a competitor?

BARDIN: So, Google Maps is about all your transportation needs, right. They have walking and they have public transit and riding and things like that. At the Waze, we only do driving. So we go really really deep on the driving experience.

So every day when you go to work, you should be using Waze. When you're in France and don't know how to get somewhere, you should use Google Maps. And so, that focus for us really allows us to go deep. We know HOV lanes and the time it takes in HOV lanes. We know the tolls and how much it costs to go to the tolls. Like we can give all that granular data that you really need every day when you're commuting.

BARTIROMO: How do you -- how do you protect people's privacy? Obviously with the Google Maps the camera is live. Your privacy, you know, you've got all of this information in there that is now accessible. How are you protecting people's privacy while doing all of this?

BARDIN: So there's a big difference between a Google product and Waze. The Google actually owns and operating system which is Android. And so there are all kinds of constraints that come with that. We play by the rules of the app stores, the Apple App Store and the Google Play App Store. And so we act like every other app that are constrained by the same rules as every other app.

So if you don't want to share anything with us, turn us off, there's no problem. But when you use Waze, the deal is quid pro quo. When you drive with us, you give us the data where you are based on how fast you're going, we can warn other drivers whether or not to drive there. You report traffic. We tell it to the drivers behind you. So it's really a community effort.

And the actual map is built by volunteers. We've got local volunteers more or less any city in the world who will update the map when a new road is opened, a new intersection. And this really gives them that hyper local feeling of how did Waze know that this intersection just show -- just opened up. Well, someone that lives there just actually made that change.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but what about this data sharing program? I mean, here too the worries over privacy come up. Tell us about the new data sharing program.

BARDIN: So Waze for cities is a program we've had for a while now. We have about 1,200 cities, partnered with transportation, municipalities connected to our platform. And we do is we share anonymous data that helps them plan their roads better.

Again, our mission is really to fight traffic and cities are very important to end this. And so, we share data back and forth, they can a close segments on our side, if there's like a big parade or a marathon, we can tell them where there are accidents.

And we have a lot of work around natural disasters, hurricanes, we will help show where to go. We'll close roads that are flooded. And it's really worked between volunteers, your elected officials and the Waze employees working together on this one platform.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you see transportation in the future? I mean, you've got A.I. obviously out there and that is bringing up the subject of driverless cars. Tell me how you see the transportation industry in general changing, let's call it in the next 20 to 50 years.

BARDIN: Well, I think there's three main trends going on. One really is electrification as cars move from fuel to electricity. The second really is transportation as a service, not owning a car but leasing a car when you need it or a car with a driver. And so -- and the third change is really the ability to have autonomy in the car that is driving by itself.

So these changes are usually plumped together but they're very, very separate. We're focused very much on transportation as a service. What we feel is that since we have multiple people driving alone the same place, if we could get them to share their car, right, we can actually make a change. (INAUDIBLE) they don't need to own two cars in your family, if we could bring it down to one car family, we've done our bid.

BARTIROMO: Noam, how are you going to -- how are you going to monetize this? Are you going to -- is there going to be a spinout of Waze at some point out of Google?

BARDIN: There's no plan to spin Waze out of Google. Right now we're not monetizing the service. And we have to actually subsidize the service to create density. If you have enough people riding and driving together to deliver --

value.Title: Washington: Conservatives Should Say NO to Google Job Offer

Extracts.SummaryText: ... The company’s plan to hire a conservative liaison and more Republican lobbyists is a continuation of Washington business as usual that Trump ran against.” “ Google ’s influence permeated the Obama administration, particularly in its ‘capture’ of its regulators. As we sought to publicize at the time, the Federal Trade Commission, and its Chair Edith Ramirez, appeared to take its direction from Google in squelching an anti-trust investigation that was recommended by its staff.” “Any conservative ...

urn:contentItem:5MDB-CN21-J9XT-P21V-00000-00Washington: Conservatives Should Say NO to Google Job Offer2016-12-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:59ZLexisNexisWashington: Conservatives Should Say NO to GoogleJob OfferNew York


Washington: National Legal and Policy Center has issued the following news release:



Reacting to reports that Googleis seeking to hire a “liaison to conservative, libertarian and free market groups,” NLPC President Peter Flaherty urged potential applicants to forget about the job. According to Flaherty:





“Googlewill pay very well and the benefits will be wonderful, but any conservative who takes this job will have to sell his or her soul. Anyone with an ounce of personal integrity should not even consider it.”



“Googleis not trying to hire a free-market advocate because it suddenly believes in free markets. It is a monopoly and it intends to stay that way. Googlewants to buy off and defuse critics who have been emboldened by the election of Donald Trump.”



“There is no, new conservative-friendly Google. The company’s plan to hire a conservative liaison and more Republican lobbyists is a continuation of Washington business as usual that Trump ran against.”



“Google’s influence permeated the Obama administration, particularly in its ‘capture’ of its regulators. As we sought to publicize at the time, the Federal Trade Commission, and its Chair Edith Ramirez, appeared to take its direction from Googlein squelching an anti-trust investigation that was recommended by its staff.”



“Any conservative or libertarian who takes a job with Googlewill be automatically suspect. I call on all the leaders of all right-of-center groups to rebuff Googleuntil there is serious change in the orientation of the company, starting with ending the censorship of conservatives in search results.”



“Googleand a handful of Bay Area companies now control the flow of online news, as more and more Americans get their news online instead of through newspapers or television. As a result, Silicon Valley is exerting ever-increasing control over politics and the government, notwithstanding Trump’s election.”



“Big Tech’s newfound political power, coupled with the hoard of personal information that these same companies compile on every American, is particularly dangerous for conservatives. No one in the conservative movement should contribute to this problem by fronting for Google.”



Last week, we sent President-elect Trump a letter warning him about the influence of Silicon Valley in advance of his meeting today with tech executives.



Except for PayPal founder Peter Theil, Silicon Valley billionaires opposed Trump’s election. Most prominent was Google’s Eric Schmidt, who was photographed election night with a “Staff” badge at Hillary’s “victory” party.



Our letter was prompted by a November 30 letter sent by tech giants to Trump urging him to adopt their policy preferences and to appoint their allies to important government posts. We ask Trump to “take their self-serving recommendations with a grain of salt.”



We provide a number of very specific warnings to Trump about the involvement of these companies with the federal government, including an account of the disastrous 18F partnership with the General Services Administration. We also specify how the priorities of Silicon Valley plutocrats are often in conflict with the interests of the middle class on issues like immigration.



NLPC has been a critic of the Obama administration’s close and often improper relationship with tech companies. Former Googleexecutive Andrew McLaughlin resigned from the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) after we demanded that he do so. Our letter to Trump describes how OSTP became little more than a lounge in the White House for Googlelobbyists.



In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com
